== Criticism == Problems of conflicting interests, of the always-permeable dichotomies of hegemony and resistance, of internal contradictions and inadequacies within the notions of the "[[human]]," "[[rights]]," "[[freedom]]," and "[[liberalism]]," shaped 19th- and early 20th-century feminist ideology and praxis and continue to resonate in debates over [[gender]], "[[Race (human categorization)|race]]," [[Social class|class]], and [[sexuality]] today.{{Citation needed|date=January 2023}} For Kyla Schuller in ''The Biopolitics of Feeling: Race, Sex, and Science in the Nineteenth Century'', "biopower is feminism's enabling condition ... movements for gender equality have materialized amid a field of power in which, at least since Malthus, the interdependence of reproduction and economics forms the primary field of the political."<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=The Biopolitics of Feeling: Race, Sex, and Science in the Nineteenth Century|last=Schuller|first=Kyla|publisher=Duke University Press|year=2018}}</ref> Schuller argues that "[the] evolutionary notion of the distinct sexes of male and female, understood as specialized divergences in physiology, anatomy, and mental function that only the most civilized had achieved, was itself a racial hierarchy ... the very idea of sex as a biological and political subjectivity is a product of the biopolitical logics unfolding hand in hand with the sciences of species change."<ref name=":2" /> Schuller quotes [[Canadians|Canadian]] philosopher [[Michelle Murphy]] in ''Seizing the Means of Reproduction: Entanglements of Feminism, Health, and Technoscience'': "Historicizing feminisms as a biopolitics that has taken 'sex,' and its subsidiary, 'reproduction,' as central concerns requires that we understand feminisms in all their variety and contradiction as animated within - and not escaping from - dominant configurations of governance and technoscience."<ref name=":2" /> From this perspective, 19th- and early 20th-century feminisms reproduced the very social hierarchies they had the potential to struggle against, exemplifying the claim of [[Michel Foucault]] in his ''The History of Sexuality, Volume I: An Introduction'' that "resistance is never in a position of exteriority in relation to power."<ref>{{Cite book|title=The History of Sexuality: Volume I: An Introduction|last=Foucault|first=Michel|publisher=Vintage Books [Random House, Inc.]|year=1990|volume=1|location=New York|pages=95}}</ref>
First-wave feminism offered no intersectional perspective. Gender was not thought of as a social construction, nor was the roles that each gender plays thought of as sexist.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Key Concepts in Feminist Theory and Research|url=https://archive.org/details/keyconceptsfemin00hugh|url-access=limited|last=Hughes|first=Christina|publisher=SAGE Publications|year=2002|isbn=978-0-7619-6987-7|location=London, California, New Delhi|pages=[https://archive.org/details/keyconceptsfemin00hugh/page/n61 47]–48}}</ref> This time period also focused on biological differences, and that only the way to be considered a woman was through biology or sex.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Feminist Theories|last=Joyce|first=Rosemary A.|publisher=Routledge|year=2000|isbn=978-0-415-13274-9|location=New York, NY|page=[https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaoffe0000unse/page/47 47]|url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaoffe0000unse/page/47}}</ref> It did not consider and fight for women of color, or women of lower socioeconomic status.<ref name=":1">{{cite thesis |last=Janowick |first=Tara |type=MA |year=2008 |title=Feminist discourse across the waves: A rhetorical criticism of first, second and third wave women's discourse |publisher=Southern Illinois University at Carbondale|id={{ProQuest|89266101}} }}</ref> It also reinforced and made colonization stronger, as well increasing the eroticization of women from different nations.<ref name=":1" /> First-wave theorists also leave out all of the activism women of color contributed. Activists like Maria Stewart, and Frances E. W. Harper are hardly mentioned with any credit for the abolitionist or suffrage movements during this time period.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://aaregistry.org/story/maria-w-stewart-an-early-abolitionist/|title=Maria W. Stewart, an early abolitionist|last=Richardson|first=Marilyn|website=AARegistry.org}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.biography.com/people/frances-ew-harper-40710|title=Frances E.W. Harper|date=1 April 2000|website=Biography.com}}</ref> First wave feminism is male centric meaning it was made in the form of the way men see women.<ref name=":1" /> Another issue with First-Wave feminism is that the white, middle-class women were able to decide what is a woman problem and what is not.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Siegel|first=Deborah L.|year=1997|title=The Legacy of the Personal: Generating Theory in Feminism's Third Wave|doi=10.1111/j.1527-2001.1997.tb00005.x|jstor=3810222|journal=Hypatia|volume=12|issue=3|pages=46–75|s2cid=145691989 }}</ref> First-wave lacked the sexual freedom women aspired to have but could not have while men could.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Feminists Theories|last=Segal|first=Lynne|publisher=Routledge|year=2014|isbn=978-0-415-13274-9|url-access=registration|url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaoffe0000unse}}</ref> It is also said that many of the white fundamental First Wave feminists were in alliance with women of color but stayed silent when they figured they could reach progression for middle class, white women.<ref>{{Cite book|title=GEXcel Work in Progress Report Volume III|last=Gunnarsson|first=Lena|publisher=GEXcel and the authors|year=2008|isbn=978-91-7393-843-3|location=Sweden|pages=27}}</ref>
